The frequency of a vibrating string is proportional to the square root of its tension
Quadrupling the tension raises the pitch by one octave
The frequency of a vibrating string is inversely proportional to the square root of its linear density
The octave corresponds to a frequency ratio of 2:1
The perfect fifth corresponds to a frequency ratio of 3:2
The perfect fourth corresponds to a frequency ratio of 4:3
The major third corresponds to a frequency ratio of 5:4
The minor third corresponds to a frequency ratio of 6:5
Consonant intervals correspond to ratios of small whole numbers
Dissonance arises from complex frequency ratios
Sound consists of periodic compressions and rarefactions of air
Pitch is determined by the frequency of aerial vibrations
The resistance of a cylindrical beam to fracture is proportional to the cube of its diameter
The resistance of a rectangular beam is proportional to the product of width and square of depth
The breaking strength of a beam is inversely proportional to its length
A beam supported at both ends can bear four times the load of a cantilever of equal dimensions
The neutral axis of a bent beam experiences neither tension nor compression
Material above the neutral axis is compressed; material below is stretched
The strength of geometrically similar structures does not scale with their size
Strength scales as the square of linear dimension; weight scales as the cube
Large animals require proportionally thicker bones than small animals
A hollow cylinder is stronger per unit weight than a solid cylinder of equal material
The optimal cross-section for a beam of given weight is hollow, not solid
Nature uses hollow structures in bones and plant stems to maximize strength per weight
Lunar mountains can be measured by the length of their shadows at the terminator
The height of a lunar mountain equals the shadow length times the sine of the solar elevation angle
Some lunar mountains exceed four Italian miles in height
The Moon's diameter is approximately one-quarter that of Earth
The distance to the Moon can be estimated from its apparent angular size
Jupiter's apparent diameter is approximately one-fifteenth that of the Moon
The periods of Jupiter's four satellites range from approximately 42 hours to 17 days
The innermost Medicean star completes its orbit in about 42 hours
The outermost Medicean star has a period of approximately 17 days
The satellites of Jupiter maintain fixed distance ratios in their orbits
The orbital radii of Jupiter's moons can be measured in Jovian diameters
Buoyant force equals the weight of fluid displaced
A body floats when its average density is less than the density of the fluid
A body sinks when its average density exceeds the density of the fluid
Ice floats because its density is approximately 9/10 that of water
The fraction of a floating body submerged equals the ratio of its density to the fluid's density
Water cannot be raised by suction pumps beyond approximately 18 braccia
The limiting height of water in a suction pump is approximately 10 meters
The resistance of a vacuum is finite and measurable
Air has weight and exerts pressure
The force required to separate two polished surfaces in contact measures the vacuum's resistance
Bodies of different weights dropped from the same height reach the ground nearly simultaneously
In a vacuum, all bodies would fall at exactly the same rate
Air resistance accounts for observed differences in fall times
Air resistance is greater for bodies of larger surface area relative to weight
Dense bodies fall faster in air than light bodies of the same size
The velocity of a falling body in a medium approaches a terminal value
Terminal velocity depends on the ratio of the body's density to the medium's density
In denser media, the same body falls more slowly
The effect of the medium is proportional to its density
The Sun rotates on its axis with a period of approximately one month
Sunspots traverse the solar disk in about 14 days
The paths of sunspots are curved when the Sun's axis is inclined to the line of sight
The apparent velocity of sunspots is greater at the solar disk's center than at the limbs
Sunspots appear foreshortened near the solar limb
The Sun's rotational axis is inclined approximately 7 degrees to the ecliptic
Sunspots vary in size from small points to areas larger than the Earth
Individual sunspots persist for days to weeks before dissolving
New sunspots form while old ones disappear
The Sun is approximately 20 times farther from Earth than the Moon
The distance to the stars is incomparably greater than the diameter of Earth's orbit
Stellar parallax would be detectable if stars were not so enormously distant
The apparent diameter of stars through the telescope is spurious, caused by irradiation
Stars appear as points when the spurious irradiation is eliminated
First magnitude stars are not necessarily closer than sixth magnitude stars
Stars may vary in intrinsic brightness, not only in distance
The Milky Way resolves into countless individual stars under magnification
Nebulae such as Praesepe resolve into star clusters
The number of visible stars increases enormously with telescopic observation
The force along a lever arm is inversely proportional to the distance from the fulcrum
The mechanical advantage of a lever equals the ratio of arm lengths
What is gained in force is lost in distance in all simple machines
The screw is an inclined plane wrapped around a cylinder
The mechanical advantage of a screw depends on the pitch
The pulley redirects force but a single fixed pulley provides no mechanical advantage
A movable pulley doubles the mechanical advantage
Block and tackle systems multiply force by the number of supporting rope segments
The wedge is a double inclined plane
All simple machines obey the principle that force times distance is conserved
The percussion of a hammer exceeds any static pressure regardless of weight
Percussion force depends on the velocity of the striking body
The effect of percussion is concentrated in a brief instant
A small hammer moving fast can drive a nail that a heavy weight resting on it cannot
The momentum of a body equals its weight times its velocity
Velocity is a continuous magnitude admitting of infinite degrees
A body cannot pass from rest to any velocity without passing through all intermediate velocities
Instantaneous velocity is the limit of average velocity over diminishing time intervals
Uniform velocity means equal distances traversed in equal times
Uniformly accelerated motion means equal increments of velocity in equal times
The ratio of distances in uniformly accelerated motion is as the squares of the times
The ratio of velocities in uniformly accelerated motion is as the times
The space traversed in accelerated motion from rest equals that traversed at half the final velocity
If velocity were proportional to distance, motion would be instantaneous
Velocity must be proportional to time, not distance, in uniformly accelerated motion
The angle of a projectile's initial velocity can be decomposed into horizontal and vertical components
The vertical component determines the time of flight
The horizontal component determines the range for a given flight time
Two projectiles with the same horizontal and vertical components will follow identical paths
The parabola is the unique curve generated by uniform horizontal and accelerated vertical motion
Any segment of a parabolic trajectory is itself parabolic
A body's natural tendency is neither upward nor downward but along its line of motion
Circular motion around Earth would be perpetual in the absence of resistance
The curvature of Earth's surface allows a horizontally projected body to travel farther before falling
At sufficient horizontal velocity, a projectile would orbit Earth without falling
The Moon's orbit is maintained by its tangential velocity
The tides result from the composition of Earth's rotation and revolution
The period of the tides should be approximately 12 hours based on this theory
Different seas have different tidal periods due to their geometry
Enclosed basins oscillate at periods determined by their length and depth
The oscillation of water in a basin is analogous to water sloshing in a moving vessel
Horizontal and vertical components of motion are mutually independent
A cannonball fired horizontally from a tower falls the same distance as one dropped
The horizontal distance traveled depends on initial horizontal velocity
The vertical distance fallen depends only on time and gravitational acceleration
Motion can be analyzed by decomposing it into independent perpendicular components
The laws of falling bodies apply equally to the vertical component of projectile motion
Pendulum motion approximates simple harmonic motion for small amplitudes
The restoring force on a pendulum is proportional to displacement for small angles
A cycloidal pendulum would be truly isochronous for all amplitudes
The brachistochrone is the path of quickest descent between two points
An arc of a circle provides faster descent than a straight incline between the same endpoints
Among all chords of a circle from the highest point, descent time is equal
The infinite can be meaningfully discussed through one-to-one correspondence
There are as many perfect squares as there are natural numbers
The part can be equal to the whole in infinite collections
Infinite quantities do not obey the axiom that the whole is greater than the part
Continuous magnitudes can be divided infinitely
Between any two points on a line there are infinitely many points
Infinitesimals are the building blocks of continuous quantities
Mathematical proof proceeds from axioms through necessary demonstration
Geometric relationships admit of certain knowledge
Physical laws have the same certainty as geometric theorems when properly demonstrated
Proportional reasoning reveals the structure of physical relationships
The fourth proportional can always be found given three magnitudes
Similar triangles yield proportions applicable to physical problems
The properties of parabolas can be derived from the definition as a conic section
The tangent to a parabola at any point makes equal angles with the axis and the focal radius
The trajectory of a projectile is tangent to its initial direction
The latus rectum of the projectile's parabola is determined by initial velocity and acceleration
Doubling initial velocity quadruples the range at the same angle
The maximum height of a projectile is proportional to the square of the vertical velocity component
The velocity at any point on the trajectory can be computed from initial conditions
A body thrown vertically upward returns with the same speed it was thrown
The time of ascent equals the time of descent for a vertically thrown body
The deceleration during ascent equals the acceleration during descent
The height reached by a vertically thrown body is proportional to the square of initial velocity
Two bodies dropped from different heights hit the ground with velocities proportional to the square roots of the heights
The velocity acquired in falling a given height is the same regardless of the path
A pendulum rises to the height from which it was released, minus frictional losses
The speed at the bottom of a pendulum swing depends only on the height of release
Work against gravity is proportional to weight times height lifted
The force required to drag a body up an inclined plane is less than lifting it vertically
The ratio of force to weight on an incline equals the ratio of height to length
The acceleration due to gravity is constant near Earth's surface
Bodies fall approximately 15 braccia in the first second from rest
In two seconds, a body falls four times the distance it falls in one second
In three seconds, a body falls nine times the first-second distance
The spacing of marks on an inclined plane reveals the square-of-time law
Water clocks can measure small time intervals for kinematic experiments
Musical rhythm provides a method for timing falling bodies
The geometric mean of two distances corresponds to the arithmetic mean of the corresponding times
The period of oscillation in a basin is proportional to the square root of length divided by depth
